subject: Sleep
title: Nighttime Dangers in History
description: A short lesson to help you apply Nighttime Dangers in History.

hook.text: Before street lights, night was genuinely dangerous. Criminals, open sewers, and wild animals owned the darkness.

buildup.text: Medieval cities imposed curfews, from the French couvre-feu, meaning cover the fire. Everyone stayed indoors after dark.

discovery.text: Night watchmen patrolled streets, and wealthy homes hired guards. Sleeping safely required active protection.

twist.text: Fear of the dark was rational for most of history. Only after gas lighting in the 1800s did nighttime become safe.

climax.text: The transformation of night from dangerous to recreational took less than 200 years of artificial lighting.

punchline.text: We conquered the night so recently that our instincts haven't caught up.
